trans-unit.source: Sometimes you want to move rigidbodies in a specific way rather than have other objects move them. For example, you might control an elevator with a script, via its Transform property, rather than have other objects push and pull it. This is a kinematic rigidbody.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes you want to move rigidbodies in a specific way rather than have other objects move them. For example, you might control an elevator with a script, via its Transform property, rather than have other objects push and pull it. This is a kinematic rigidbody.

trans-unit.source: Although kinematic rigidbodies aren't moved by physics, other objects can still collide with them. For example, in the case of the elevator, objects placed inside won't fall through the elevator floor.
trans-unit.target: Although kinematic rigidbodies aren't moved by physics, other objects can still collide with them. For example, in the case of the elevator, objects placed inside won't fall through the elevator floor.

trans-unit.source: Select the entity you want to be a kinematic rigidbody.
trans-unit.target: Select the entity you want to be a kinematic rigidbody.

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid, under the Rigidbody component properties, select Is kinematic.
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid, under the Rigidbody component properties, select Is kinematic.

trans-unit.source: You can script the Is kinematic property to turn on and off on certain events. For example, imagine our kinematic elevator's suspension cables are cut. You can script the Is kinematic property to change to false when this happens. The elevator becomes subject to the usual forces of physics, and falls.
trans-unit.target: You can script the Is kinematic property to turn on and off on certain events. For example, imagine our kinematic elevator's suspension cables are cut. You can script the Is kinematic property to change to false when this happens. The elevator becomes subject to the usual forces of physics, and falls.
